Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Basic understanding of python and artificial intelligence
A better picture of looking at the development of AI.
I learned a smattering of various topics in artificial intelligence.
AI I guess?
This course gave a good overview of topics in Artificial Intelligence as well as accompanying workload to learn the techniques.
I learned a great deal about the complexities of artificial intelligence, especially in regards to driverless cars.

A overview of artificial intelligence topics, search algorithms and agents, game playing agents, natural language processing, first order logic, propositional logic, reinforcement learning, neural networks... It's a lot of topics.

AI is an intense but very informative course touching on many AI topics and relevant applications. Among other things, working with a lot of distribution code and thinking critically about algorithms, research papers were important parts of the class.
General insights about neural networks and reinforcement learning
General knowledge about AI and current developments in the field
Everything from Game playing to Machine learning (Artificial Neural Nets, learning...) to search.

I feel much more familiar with neural networks, supervised learning, and reinforcement learning concepts. I finally understand how AI works and can take it from there to learn more about specific things that interest me the most in this field.
Basic and advanced knowledge in different fields in AI.

Survey class of Artificial Intelligence.

Learned some machine learning as well as some general categories of problems and types of algorithms.
A knowledge of the theory and technique of several fields within artificial intelligence.
Machine learning techniques, search techniques, NLP
I learned about the AI in detail from more than a theoretical standpoint.
I got a solid understanding of deep learning, reinforcement learning, search algorithms and other important topics in Artificial Intelligence.
Learnt about deep learning, logic, Bayesian Networks, and several other cutting edge topics. Also learnt to work with python, numpy, new tools like tensorflow.
General understanding of AI techniques

I developed very few skills by taking this course. Since the sheer amount of material was so overwhelming, I definitely gained a wide breadth of knowledge; however, I don't actually understand very many things that were covered. Although I went through 90% of the slides and reading chapters listed for the final, the exam tested about 20% of the material I learned, and I felt like I would have gotten practically the same exact score had I taken the exam without taking the class.

As you know, AI is huge and hot now. You gain exposure to concepts like recurrent neural networks, reinforcement learning, which are incredibly applicable to current concepts (chess agents like Alpha Zero, image recognition, machine translation). These are all huge concepts and say things about intelligence in general. You also learn to do object-oriented programming in psets. Building agents that can solve specific problems and seeing them run is a very satisfying experience. You get an overview of the areas in AI, starting from search and problem solving then moving through logic, language, learning (supervised, reinfocement).
I learned a lot about neural networks, logic in AI, and machine learning.
Learned about a number of AI techniques.

I learned a very shallow amount of information on a very broad array of topics. This class was very much an introduction to Artificial Intelligence in that a lot of topics were covered, but no one topic was covered in great depth. We learned the basics of AI, search algorithms, logic, some probability, neural networks, etc.
Survey of many of the major areas of AI problem solving both historical and cutting edge.

We learned the fundamental algorithms and different types of agents for artificial intelligence. We learned an array of concepts, some of which include search approaches, neural networks, probabilistic agents, and reinforcement learning.
Learned about techniques and algorithms in AI I wasn't aware of before, some hands-on experience with implementing them.
The course did little to teach me anything. Learned more from online videos (Stanford, MIT etc).
I learned some of the basics of Artificial Intelligence.

I had never taken a CS course at Yale. I had previous coding experience, where I usually taught myself and used it in my research. This class definitely filled in many holes that I had in my programming and computer science knowledge, as well as expanding it with the many interesting topics we covered. I learned more about thinking about computer science on a theoretical level rather than just a practical one, though I'm glad I took it Pass/Fail.

 It was really great to take a course in a field that is modern and progressing very quickly. I hope to use what I learned here in my own research in the future.
Reinforcement learning, search algorithms, game playing AI

We scratched the surface of AI. It is such a big field that it's impossible to cover everything in depth. We use Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach as our textbook, and since this textbook is very popular in other courses at other institutions, you can check out their versions online to see what's covered. (Berkeley AI is a good example.)
Everything from perceptrons to recurrent neural networks. You learn about the core concepts and algorithms that drive all kinds of artificially intelligent agents.

I learned quite a lot about the applications of artificial intelligence. This was by all definitions a broad survey course. We touched the surface of many concepts, but I don't think I deeply understood many of them.
Mostly algorithms related to artificial intelligence.
I learned different strategies for creating and optimizing artificial intelligence in a variety of contexts (mostly games).
Covers search, NLP, perceptrons. Overview of major AI topics.

AI is an incredibly interesting topic. This course is very very broad survey style. All of the cool concepts are at least put up on a slide. Whether you actually learn them is very much up to you outside of class, but they are at least presented.
Covered a bunch of topics but not in great depth. Covered search algorithms, neural nets, NLP, etc.
Great intro to a lot of different topics in AI
Learned the basics of AI; actually learned about how neural nets worked for the first time, which was cool
A good overview of artificial intelligence theory and implementation.
This class was an excellent survey of into topics in Artificial Intelligence, including an overview of many cutting-edge techniques.
Learnt more about different approaches to AI and the techniques used in AI.

This course was a perfect combination of the foundations and modern techniques in AI. On the foundations side, we looked at search algorithms (depth-first, breadth-first, uniform cost / Dykstra, greedy best-first, A star + heuristics, and gameplay minimax with alpha-beta pruning); we showed the generality of these techniques with applications in gameplay, constraint satisfaction, and NP-complete problems. We also covered logic and theorem proving, decision trees, dimensionality reduction, probability, and Bayes nets. On the modern / sexy side, we covered neural nets in great detail (SVM, Softmax loss functions; stochastic gradient descent parameter updates; intuitions about hyperparamenters and convergence; fully-connected and convolutional layers for image classification and reinforcement learning; recurrent, LSTM, and attention architectures for semantic parsing). We also looked at Markov models (Markov reward processes, decision processes, POMDPs) and related algorithms (value and policy iteration, Q-learning) which was perhaps my favorite part of the course. 

This course also found a balance between theory and implementation. The lectures stay high-level, allowing for exposure to and synthesis of an immense field. In the psets, we dove in head first to the most crucial algorithms covered in class. The last two projects feature 1. (Supervized learning) - neural-net image classification on the CIFAR-10 data set and 2. Reinforcement Q-learning in the Pacman and Atari environments. Both projects were fun to show off to friends and family.

Why does it matter? In addition to its applicability in most jobs and areas of scientific and digital humanities research, AI is the noblest and most ambitious experiment undertaken by humankind (since freedom). In AI, we are trying to formalize the principles of our rationality, to extend and surpass our minds, to understand who and what we are. Join us!

The subject matter for this class was very interesting and the textbook was quite engaging and easy to follow. However, the professor's lectures were fast-paced, to say the least, and I felt like I was unable to gain much from the few lectures I could bring myself to attend.
The textbook was great I learned a lot about different types of techniques used in artificial intelligence.
What artificial intelligence entails, logic, neural networks, probability
I became more familiar with the techniques of artificial intelligence and neural networks. I'm now more comfortable reading papers in these fields.

In AI 470 I learned some of the basic concepts in AI like the different agents and environments out there, games and propositional and first-order logic and some of the more complicated topics like neural networks and reinforcement learning. And for each of the main topics we had a coding assignment that helped us understand the material.
A general overview of the history and the latest developments in AI

This class is an intro/survey of the basics of artificial intelligence. Most of the classwork will be building/coding agents for various games. Some concepts covered are search, learning, logic, and statistics.
Decent intro to AI. You learn more from psets than class
Not too much. I learned what a wumpus was.

A lot of content was covered in this course, to the extent that I'm not sure I got to understand things as deeply as I would've liked. That said, it was at least good to know all the different subfields that've historically been part of what's called AI. One thing I also appreciated was how the assignments got us familiar with a number of contemporary machine learning libraries, like Theano and Tensorflow, both of which I'd never used before. Even though it was hard work trying to figure out the APIs sometimes, now I feel more confident using those libraries in the future. Also, programming AIs to play games was just pretty fun to watch.
Definition of artificial intelligence; forms of AI; AI problem solving, logic, learning
This class simply rips off problem sets from other universities. This means there is often a mismatch between what we learn in class and what we are expected to do in our homework.
Very interesting knowledge.
The course covers some very interesting topics, but it covers too much.  It would be better if the course we split up into multiple courses.
It's cool material, but presented kind of poorly.

Many of the shortcomings of this course this semester were the result of Teaching Assistants (poor understanding of the problem sets they themselves assigned or incorrect grading on exams and a lack of communication, etc.). In terms of strengths, Professor Radev has a very well-thought-out curriculum and is a good lecturer as well.

The assignments are all taken directly from Berkeley and Stanford, meaning that the lecture slides and videos from these classes can serve as supplemental materials to the lectures on campus. The programming assignments are all in Python, except for one pen-and-paper mathematical problem set. This means that the language is applicable to real-world work. 

The main weakness of the course is related to the exams. The review sessions leading up to the exams involve the professor skimming through old lecture notes during class, not providing much substantive review. There is not much clarity before exams about what will be covered, as the only review material provided is exams from other universities, including questions not related to content covered in CPSC 470.
Survey courses covering a lot of material, in not much depth. Very confusing to follow at times because we did not go into much detail.

CPSC 470 covered way TOO much material, in not enough depth, meaning that students were left with a very surface-level understanding that wasn't terribly useful for solving problems. At this point, I think AI is just too broad a field to do justice to in a single course. Students are better off taking separate classes on individual subfields, i.e. logic (PHIL 115), machine learning (S&DS 365), robotics (CPSC 472 and 473), computer vision (CPSC 475 and 476), NLP (CPSC 477), and decision-making (not offered). 

While this class was too broad in some ways, it was also not broad enough in others! It all but omitted several central components of AI  things that I was expecting and hoping would be covered  including convolutional neural networks and  backpropagation. 

The class just didn't work, and studying for exams was incredibly frustrating. If it were up to me, I would say eliminate it altogether, and encourage students to explore the subfields that most interest them. As it stands, this class is a waste of time.

There are wayyyy too many slides per lecture (about 120 slides/lecture). So it was a bit hard to study before the exam. A lot of the material were from the Berkeley CS188 class which is nice because there's a lot of resources available online, but it's still hard to keep up during class (even if you pay full attention in class) because Drago just flips through the slides so fast.

The course needs to be better organized in terms of relating content to the homework material, as well as the pacing and emphasis of certain key concepts. 

Lecture slides were unnecessarily long, would be good if examples were run through by hand to aid teaching as well as through slides.

In a couple of years I expect this course to be excellent; in its first year being taught, assignments were new, so specifications contained mistakes and other things that caused misunderstandings and confusions. That was the main problem with the course. The material is very relevant and exactly what one would expect out of a well-structured, intensive intro to AI

Too difficult, too many topics. Problem sets were either far too easy or completely impossible based on what had been taught in lecture and assigned as reading. The final exam was absolutely perverse, and tested knowledge that was completely outside the bounds of the syllabus. Lectures were nearly useless, and whenever the material strayed from the textbook, it felt like there was nowhere to turn. All the course materials were delegated out to a vast teaching staff, so often different parts of assignments did not agree with each other and proved impossible without diligently checking the course Piazza for updates.

The main strength of the course is that it was so difficult that it motivated me to seek out materials from other courses in order to teach myself the material. This is unacceptable that I had to do this, but often the course staff was open about the fact that we needed to do this in order to adequately learn the material. I learned plenty due to this course, but no thanks to the course itself. Also, the textbook is generally extremely strong, so whenever the course material relates to what's in the textbook, you can usually learn it independently. This became less true for the later material. The textbook became fairly inscrutable when it came to probability and reinforcement learning, so I had to seek out other materials online.

Strengths are that it is a very relevant topic that I'm glad is now included at Yale. Weaknesses are that some of the organization of the class could be improved but that is understandable because it is the first time it is offered.
Better organization of Homeworks, less material focus on search and games.

The strengths are a lot of cutting edge material is covered which is very interesting. The weakness is that some of the problem sets were quite difficult and some of the technologies weren't taught in class which made the assignments even harder.
It was great.

This class has no organization at all. Professor Drago has on average 100 slides per lecture and goes over some complicated concepts about AI in only a few minutes which makes the class very disorienting. Also, usually half of his slides are straight-up ripped from either Stanford's course or Berkeley's course, which makes it even more disorienting because they often contain abbreviations or terms that were never even introduced to us. Furthermore, there was one homework assignment that we were given two weeks to do that was an entire's semester's worth of homework for an ADVANCED computer vision class at UC Berkeley. 

The class can be dramatically improved if Drago narrowed down the topics for this class. He needs to limit his slides to something reasonable like 30/lecture so that students can actually leave the class with a solid grasp of certain concepts. It's no surprise why attendance for this large lecture completely dropped to the point where Davies Auditorium had only about 4 rows of people in it in some classes.
Great class - Drago did an amazing job of revamping the AI offering at Yale. Its a lot of work but the material is engaging and interesting
The strength is that the course covers a wide range of topics, but the course lacks better design. Also the lectures are not attractive.

Strengths: Interesting material. First half on search was well organized
Weaknesses: Messy and unstructured teaching that devolved throughout the semester. Teaching on neural networks was a mess, and everything after and including the second half of first-order logic was not taught well. Homework and practice assignments were often copied whole-scale from other universities (Stanford, Berkeley) without adjusting for the type of content that we had learnt (which was different compared to them)

Not many people show up to lecture. Some of the material is interesting, but because it's such a big class, everyone's coding ability varies a lot.

Would be more interesting as a smaller class with a specific level of prerequisite. This class was too broad and general to come out of it as having learned how to implement anything specific.
Covers a lot, but that makes it hard to get an in-depth understanding of any of the topics. Would recommend taking a logic course before.

Since the course was being offered for the first time and content was pulled from many different sources, it was a bit hard to follow along with the material. I think the machine learning instruction and in particular the mathematical homework for machine learning was helpful. Another area for improvement was that the homework and lectures didn't align well.
The class is interesting, but the psets are not related to the lectures and the lectures are not in depth.

weaknesses - the professor is sometimes monotonous and listening to lecture is hard. The professor commonly refers to things as "easy", "simple" etc. and makes you feel less smart. Additionally, there is far too much material for a semester.

The strengths of the course are the vast and incredibly interesting subject matter. The psets were also fun to do. The main weakness I'd say was lecture. We simply covered too much to really understand all of it so it kind of flew by.

This course gives a very good  insight into several different topic. Drago is a great professor, who is very approachable. It also helps work with some of the latest research in the field. One improvement could be to have more problem sets like Pset5, which give a deeper understanding into the specific working of a praticular topic.

Weakness:
Assignments were directly copied from other schools' classes/web.

Tries to cover too much material at a surfacial level
Too much breadth, not enough depth. This class could be taught much better in two or three semesters.

Lectures were not very well organized. 

Extra-lecture suggested materials from its sister courses in Berkeley and Stanford were helpful and informative.

You learn a lot from doing the psets and implementing the algorithms themselves. The TFs are extremely helpful and qualified.

Classes felt like they went on for years. Drago didnt seem that interested in what he was saying, most of the slides werent his, and I never really knew when to pay attention. Most people either didnt show up or didnt pay attention.
Interesting Content

This class covered lots of interesting subject matter. While it is a survey class we did go into some depth on things like deep learning and reinforced learning which are very interesting. That said, the quality of the teaching is very poor. Drago seems like a nice person who cares genuinely about his students but he is a very bad communicator. This results in lectures which are impossible to follow as well as unintelligible exam questions. For instance, i have never seen so many people go up to ask questions during an exam as I did during this classes final. Nearly every question required significant clarification. I left the exam wishing I hadn't studied, not because the exam was easy, but because the hardest part was figuring out what the questions were asking. Drago could definitely improve as a professor with time, but one does get the sense that everyone would be better off if he were spending his time researching instead.

It is hard to evaluate this class because it was taught by a new instructor. That being said, there were several glaring weaknesses this semester. 

The first weakness is the problem sets. The problem sets varied wildly in the difficulty of the assignment. Some problem sets were very straightforward, taking maybe only a couple hours to complete. However, other problem sets were much, much longer. These problem sets were made much harder because we weren't taught how to do these assignments, but rather meant to learn how to do them on their own. While this normally wouldn't be an issue, on one problem set we were essentially expected to learn about half of a Stanford class's worth of material (they gave us the lecture notes for that class to learn). It seems very unreasonable to make us learn an entire other course's material to complete a problem set. Please fix this for future classes. 

I think the weakness of this class was that it was kind of tough to tie together all of the material. This is definitely difficult to handle because of the survey nature of this class, but I didn't really get how the different subjects fit together until I was studying for the final exam. 

Furthermore, the TA's for this class were generally subpar. I understand that they were essentially forced to TA this class, but they were very difficult to work with because they were not familiar with the problem sets that they didn't write (as each TA wrote a different problem set, which made continuity between problem sets awful).

Finally, the last weakness is that the lecture slides are way too disorganized. The initial slide decks were good, but towards the end way too much material was just copy and pasted from different courses at other universities. This was very confusing to follow, especially when slides from different courses were interleaved. 

For a strength, I guess the content is interesting.

Drago is a really nice professor and the material is fascinating and super relevant. It was frustrating how disorganized some of the psets and exams were. Would be a fantastic course after some polishing.

I took Drago's NLP course last semester and thought that the course was pretty well structured and had similar expectations for AI. However, the class definitely is going through some growing pains because the problem sets are not well organized and the lectures could be improved. I feel like more focus could be put into specfic topics rather than trying to cover as many topics as possible.
The problemsets should be made more substantial, so that more thinking is required. The slides should ideally have less topics, but have more content on each topic.
Didn't learn anything substantial from the course -- I learned more from watching stanford lectures online (where all the psets were copied from anyway)

The course has some strengths; parts of the problem set were interesting. But it was often poorly thought through. One of the psets, for example, had random chunks pulled from different sections of another courses full semester work that resulted in us learning little to nothing. Parts were often left unexplained in a way that made it difficult in a way that was frustrating but did not allow me to learn much at all. The tests did not adequately reflect what we had learned. Less material should be taught more clearly in lecture, and that is what should be tested.

Strengths - it's such an interesting topic. Weaknesses - the execution. The lectures were far too general and not focused enough. It would be much better if we went into depth in a few fundamental topics rather than surveying a ton of algorithms that nobody truly understands.

Strength: I like that we try to use a lot of modern technology in our homework and that Drago always keeps us up to date with interesting papers / videos.
Weakness: I think the lectures should be more systematic and cleaner. There shouldn't be slides that we will never go through in the lectures. It's very confusing.

The class tried to fit in a lot of things, which traded off depth for breadth. Lectures go at a breakneck pace and it's hard to follow sometimes -- I only really understood and appreciated the material when I sat down to study it at the end.

The class also relies on course material from other schools (read: Stanford and Berkeley) a lot, which is understandable because there's no point reinventing the wheel, but it's not ported over well yet so sometimes you're thrown into the psets without the lectures/notes that should have come with them. Fortunately they're not very hard so you can figure it out after a bit.

This course covered a lot of intellectually stimulating and technically complex topics; however, I felt this course lacked structure and because so many topics were covered, a lot of them were glossed over and not gone over in as much depth as I would have preferred.

Professor Radev needs to stop ripping off other professors' resources. It would have been preferable to just go through one professor's course as opposed to learning a little bit of everything (but only the easy parts).

Search, Minimax, and First order logic were well taught, the other parts of the course were a little more scattered, I suspect because it had to be developed mid semester. I'm sure it's going to be an incredible course after a few iterations.

I think the class could be improved if the psets covered more of the class material.  To some degree, they would, but it was very difficult getting through certain psets and having to learn it all on the fly (Tensorflow, Convolutional NNs, etc).  I also think that the PowerPoint format is not the best way to convey the information.

Professor Radev's clearly very interested in the subject, but perhaps due to the first-time nature of the course this year, the course as a whole felt quite disjointed; the mixed-and-matched lectures and homework assignments probably contributed somewhat to this. If you're interested in AI, this course is worth considering, but Lafferty's Machine Learning course may also be a good alternative.

Strengths- psets are applied, practical, good coverage of topics
Weaknesses- lectures not at all related to either psets or exams, need to self study entirely

This course covers way too much material and Drago doesn't put enough time into really explaining any of it. It has the characteristics of what a good CS course should be at Yale (we should have lots more AI courses) but it just never got there. The assignments in particular were not well structured and were incredibly frustrating at times as well. Because we didn't learn anything, the exams were way way way too hard and just total crapshoots. Grading was generous in the end though as long as you did well on the psets.

To do the assignments you needed to do a lot of learning on your own. The covered topics was good, but I think we should have dug into some more. The skeleton code for the first two assignments was good, but after that there was too much stuff there. The Neural Net assignments had too much background stuff. I think lecture could have covered more relevant to what we were working on.

The lectures have nothing to do with the exams. The slides have WAY too much content and are often just borrowed from other professors. This is unacceptable. Either the course must go through all the slides or just link us to the lectures that were originally given using them so that we can learn the material properly. Some of the problem sets also had nothing to do with the content learned during the course.
The slides are really hard to understand. Requires a lot of self teaching.

This class has excellent psets: working through assignments was both fun and informative, and really drove concepts home. However, a greater cohesion between assignments and lecture would improve the course: often I felt as though we had covered a topic in very general terms in class, but then went in depth on psets. For math-based topics, this was particularly frustrating.

Problem sets greatly facilitated learning (they required some thinking), though more support and tutorials on using libraries and frameworks such as TensorFlow would be good. Also 60% of the class got an A, which seems to be ridiculous - given that the class doesn't have a very heavy workload to begin with, this means that many would be able to get an A without putting in a commensurate amount of effort.

Strengths: this course very ambitiously holds your hand all the way out to the cliff and cutting edge of modern AI research. Drago is such a nice person who really cares for his students.
Weaknesses: The staff could have been stiffer on deadlines and done a better job of setting expectations on psets. There could be more frequent checkins to make sure we were on target. In lecture, although I like that Drago stays high level, more specific guidance on the most important algorithms could be given. Drago draws on slides from multiple sources, and sometimes the notation can be variant and confusing.
Improvements: I think the kinks in the psets will work themselves out going forward. Having an ability to see the results of especially pset 3 (semantic parsing) more clearly would be nice. In lecture, try to draw on at most one source of slides per topic to minimize confusion.

The course was overly ambitious in the sense that not only did it cover a lot of material, it also assumed that we were covering everything in depth. The lecture slides provided by the professor were very difficult to understand. The expectations for the exams were also very unclear and the final exam tested material no-one really understood. I believe that the course would benefit from being converted into a 2-semester long sequence that actually covers the material in depth and not just expects us to understand everything on our own.

The content of the course was interesting. However, the execution was less than ideal, especially since this was the first year of the course. Some of the homework assignments were disorganized and duplicates from other courses. There isn't anything wrong with using assignments from other courses, but it was clear that not much work was put into making sure the material was suitable for the class (HW4 in particular). The final was also not representative of the material of the course, with almost 20% of the points focused on one topic which was barely covered. The pseudocode in the textbook was nearly impossible to understand.

The course material in general is pretty engaging, though a bit dry at times. It's helpful that the problem sets line up pretty close to the material, which, surprisingly, can't necessarily be said for all CS courses at Yale. However, there were times where the material was a bit more nebulous than it should have been, lending to a torrent of questions on Piazza.

Course was WAY too broad, psets were way too hard. I think the instructor could've gone into topics more in depth, and actually built out the logical steps to some of the techniques rather than glossing over them and expecting us to actually execute in the problem sets.

TA support was poor. PSETs were absolutely terrible  too difficult.
Homework concepts did not overlap with lecture at all and we were expected to do things that were never remotely covered in lecture; lectures were really boring

This course is an amalgamation of other professors' slides and notes that are read by Drago in class. Other courses focus on teaching key course concepts, but Drago focuses on covering as much material as possible, but it's his first time with this course, so I think he'll improve the course greatly over the years. I think that mandatory section to go over algorithms and course concepts in depth would be very useful, as our ULAs didn't seem to have a clear teaching function, other than to answer questions on Piazza, which was flooded with information, sometimes course critical. More often than not, our prep material for exams would be straight from UC Berkeley, which has a very well taught course, but Drago did not adapt this material to be used in the course he taught, which was very frustrating.

Weaknesses of this course were mainly related to the homework, their level of difficulty, how many office hours were offered..etc.. 
First off, most of the homework's spec was very unclear and wasn't directly covering the material taught in lecture. The lectures mainly covered the material found in the textbook with some elaboration, whereas in some cases, specially when a homework was due, what I personally needed most is more guidance on how to approach the homework and what things I needed to know about it. (That improved towards the end of course when the professor and TA's started to explain what is unclear about the homework.) That could have saved a lot of the time spent on understanding the pset. There should also be more office hours or at least longer sessions, since there are many students in the class, 2 hours are not enough to help 20 students. There are many strengths to this class however. The topic is very interesting, more so than some other courses I have taken at Yale. That helped me enjoy studying the material for the tests. This course has also provided me with some of the basic tools I would need for AI and computer science in general and strengthened my coding skills in python and in general.

Strengths: 
The materials are very up-to-date. We read papers published a few months ago, and the professor edited slides to include the latest findings. 
This course cites multiple similar classes at Stanford and Berkeley etc., thus provides a good depth and breath for an introduction to AI.

Weakness:
Sometimes the slides feel disorganized (as they were taken from slides at other schools), and the lectures are not very engaging.

The class borrows a lot of assignments/lectures from other classes, which can sometimes be a bit disorganized. Lecture engagement is pretty low with students simply reading through the lecture slides rather than coming in. It does cover a number of interesting concepts (though sometimes things are left to the student to figure out without much explanation).

The lectures were dry and taken out of the textbook mostly. Also there was wayyyy too much information crammed in, so studying for tests consisted of going through hundreds of lecture slides and wondering which topics were relevant enough to study in depth (that led to a lot of curveballs on tests where topics that we barely covered suddenly were very important to know for the test)
Teaching largely recycled textbook readings; material was rather dry. Strengths included the lightning fast instructor response times on Piazza.

The breath of the content was good, as was the exposure to contemporary machine learning environments and algorithms through the assignments. That said, the lectures themselves were less engaging than I'd expected -- I think partly because the slides didn't always seem the most organized, and I find it hard to understand algorithms quickly by reading the pseudocode on a screen. Perhaps it would have been better to do things graphically on the chalkboard where possible. The late afternoon timing also made it harder to stay awake, at least in my experience. All that said, this course was a *lot* better than the previous incarnation of AI at Yale, which I audited briefly and soon stopped attending.

Strengths
- interesting and pertinent core content
- textbook used is seminal in the field
- professor was very engaged in course administration

Weaknesses
- organization of lecture content is not engaging
- use of other school course material
No, not in its current state.
Yes!
I would not recommend this course as is: it simply covers too much material too fast to facilitate student learning.
Nah. Too much work for what you learn.

This course is definitely still worth taking for those interested in the field of Artificial Inteligence. Still, I wouldn't take it with the expectation of it being extremely intensive in coding or provide exceptional depth.

For anyone interested in artificial intelligence, this course is the best offering at Yale. Being able to get firsthand experience with Tensorflow is very important, as is gaining a deeper understanding of the mathematical equations that power some of the most advanced computer science of the modern world.

Absolutely do not take this course. I thought it would improve with Drago teaching, instead it was an utter disaster.

For context: I am a senior, I attended every class, and I had close to a 100% going into the final. So believe me when I say that (1) no part of this course was easy to understand in any sort of depth, and (2) this is probably the worst class I have taken at Yale. 

In more detail: Virtually all of Drago's powerpoints are just taken from other people, which means they're a disorganized jumble of different presentations, often 100s of slides long. Class itself is incredibly boring, with Drago just reading from the slides and doing very little to frame the material in a way that makes it sound interesting/easier to understand. The problem sets either don't relate to what we covered in class at all (e.g. Problem Set 4, which involves implementing different classifiers using algorithms we did not go over, including backprop [HOW CAN YOU NOT COVER BACKPROP IN AN AI CLASS?!]) or can be completed with minimal understanding of the underlying concepts (e.g. Problem Sets 3 and 6, which effectively asked you to implement equations that were given). The exams sometimes felt like non-sequiturs, e.g. three questions about multi-class perceptrons on the final  yet another topic we quite simply did not cover in class! Overall, the class tries to cover way too many (sometimes irrelevant) topics at once, while omitting others that you wish it did cover. The net result is that you often don't actually understand anything you're doing and end up scrambling come exam-time.

Ultimately, it's difficult to know how to allocate blame here. I think Drago does mean well, and I've heard mostly good things about his NLP class. But it would take an incredibly gifted, dedicated teacher to make a class of this scope work, and Drago couldn't manage it. I would STRONGLY recommend that anyone interested in AI take one of Yale's alternative courses in more specific subfields, like machine learning (S&DS 365), robotics (CPSC 472 and 473), computer vision (CPSC 475 and 476), or NLP (CPSC 477). I just wish someone had told me that before I wasted a semester on this class.
Yes, definitely recommend, for the material as well as for Drago.

Yes, because the material is fascinating and essential. But with grave reservations regarding the difficulty and the amount of independent study that you need to do to pass.

I would also encourage anyone considering the course to practice vectorized programming before beginning. Knowledge of Python was insufficient to complete the psets. Some of the psets also tested vectorized programming in the TensorFlow and NumPy libraries, which is completely different from general Python programming. These psets were nearly impossible for me, because I had never coded in these libraries or worked with R, etc.
Yes, especially if you are interested in this area of CS!
Only if you are extremely interested in the material.

If you are really interested in AI then it can be a good way to cover many of the concepts. The lectures covered a lot of important topics related to AI and theory behind it. The problem sets can be quite challenging especially because you are expected to learn libraries on your own. Just be prepared to absorb a lot of material.
No
Absolutely take this class if you can muster the time commitment to learn this interesting material
Come on this is AI what other choice do you have.

I wouldn't recommend this course because it's really poorly organized. You don't really get much out of the lectures. The first smaller half on Search was sort of good but everything else became an increasing mess as the course proceeded. The assignments aren't even original (i.e. made at Yale) but copied almost without any changes from other universities (Stanford, Berkeley), which shows you how much thought went into preparing this course.

I would recommend this as a gut elective for CS. If you are looking to learn something, I would take the machine learning class instead. This class is for a very low commitment level (i.e. not showing up to class). With that said, Drago is very nice, and he is very respectable as a professor.
Gives you a good overview of the field. Psets are not that hard, but the tests are brutal. Tries to cover too much in-depth.

Take this class if you want a good survey of all the subfields of AI. But be warned that it is not very well organized and you may feel unprepared to solve some of the homeworks based on what is taught in the class.
No, I would not recommend this course to another student. I don't feel like I learned much the whole semester and the tests were extremely stressful.
Yes the material and Psets were great. only downside is a somewhat hard to follow lecture.

Yes. This is a great course which is definitely worth taking. Drago is a very knowledgeable and approachable professor, and the material is very interesting. The course definitely helps you learn a lot about the newest AI techniques and research papers, and covers a huge breadth of topics.

No. 

It is a direct copy of courses available on Coursera/Edx. better to study from those sources
No, not unless it was restructured.

Yes, if you need a survey to AI then you gotta take this. It's not the best one out there but it's the only one at Yale. Honestly if you have a deep interest in specific areas like deep learning or language processing it might just be better to take an online course in that area.

I hope this class improves. The material is great, the psets are interesting, but the delivery is pretty bad. I was disappointed because it was hard to stay motivated in the class when the professor doesnt own the material and the TFs dont know the psets.
I would recommend this class if Yale could find someone else to teach it.

First of all, this course is horribly disorganized. If this course is better organized the next semester it is taught, it would be a much better class. Right now the problem sets and lecture slides are horribly disorganized, making the class quite unpleasant. 

If nothing is done to change the problem sets, the experience of this class will be awful. In fact, one of the problem sets I did this semester in this class was by far the worst problem set I've ever done in the sense that it will horribly frustrating. I've taken 323, but even this problem set was more infuriating to work on because it was clear the instructors had no idea how to make a problem set that was the correct length, nor were we taught any of the relevant material to do the problem sets. 

The exams were very strange. The midterm was quite easy, and the final was very difficult. The practice materials we were given were extremely unhelpful as they were just taken from a different university's course, and they did not reflect the material on the actual exams. 

In the end, I would recommend this class to anyone who wanted a broad survey of AI. If the problem sets remain unchanged, be prepared for a class whose workload fluctuates wildly (between trivial problem sets that are still frustrating because the grading is unclear and the longest, most poorly written problem sets that you are not appropriately taught for).
Yes. AI is an extremely relevant topic of study for computer scientists today. Also from what I understand, this class is a vast improvement over its previous form.

If you are looking for a CS elective that does not have that much of a workload but covers pretty interesting topics, then AI is the class for you. But, you will also have to endure some poor organization throughout the semester.  I would also not recommend the course for people who have not taken 223 yet, although the prereqs only say 201. Having 223 under your belt makes the class a lot easier.

This was all around a terrible course. Compared to other artificial intelligence courses at other universities, I felt like we had learned maybe 10% as much material, but were accountable for all of the knowledge we were never taught - ONE of our psets consisted of questions from MULTIPLE psets from a course CENTERED ON MACHINE VISION, while we did not even get one fully comprehensible lecture on the topic. The course was highly disorganized and it seemed like only one TA understood a PSET at any one time (that is, the one they were in charge of...). The lectures were useless, and the slides were even more so - they were basically a disorganized combination of slides from other courses. The textbook was long and hard to understand on its own, but was probably the only reliable source of information. Arguably one of the worst courses offered at Yale.
Don't go in expect to learn from class. Read the textbooks yourself and watch videos if needed. Use the class to do the problem sets.

A terrible elective, but it's all Yale CS has on AI -- you'll take this course, learn little, likely regret it. Too large, not structured well, doesn't teach much. Do yourself a favour and watch the Stanford lectures instead
I guess. We don't have a lot of good CS elective options. I hope it will improve before it is taught again.

I would not recommend this course. Most people stopped going to class because the lectures were too general and not helpful for the assignments. The class overlaps a lot with NLP - just take that class instead because that's what Drago is an expert in and enjoys teaching. The psets are taken from other AI courses, but we never learned the same material in depth, so we had literally had to watch Stanford lectures to finish the assignment. I learned more watching those lectures than I did in the whole semester of this class. Unless the lectures get much better, don't be drawn in by the name of this class - the execution is lacking.

I feel like a lot of the materials are readily available online. Unless the professor can provide you with intuitive and interesting lectures, I think taking an online version at your own pace is probably better.

There's a good reason why this class is the most subscribed class in the CS department this semester -- definitely take it if you have the chance. Hopefully after a few policy iterations from Drago the class will get even better.

P.S. join the bless me lord drago FB group if you haven't already
Think it's going to be amazing once the kinks are worked out.
Yes, I think it's important for people interested in the subject to take this course.

I have mixed feelings about this course  Professor Radev's clearly very interested in the subject, but perhaps due to the first-time nature of the course this year, the course as a whole felt quite disjointed; the mixed-and-matched lectures and homework assignments probably contributed somewhat to this. If you're interested in AI, this course is worth considering, but Lafferty's Machine Learning course may also be a good alternative.

AI is useful to learn, and this course provided motivation for me to learn it. That being said, everything I learned was from online resources/materials from Berkeley and Stanford. Lectures had zero relation to either psets or exams. The course this semester was rough, but I imagine that after a semester of teaching it, Drago will be able to significantly improve the class for next year.

AI could definitely get better if feedback is listened to. I would consider taking it in the future and it was still the CS course I think I would have enjoyed most this semester. Still, given how good this material is, the fact that this course was so frustrated and not suited to learning was really a letdown.

If you want a class that is not too much work and covers some interesting topics go for it. If you actually want to learn the topics you will have to go above and beyond on the assignments and learn on your own.
Yup! Great intro to AI

. A quick point before I go into my review of the course: Radev is very receptive to students and always has things graded promptly. If you're worried about grades, 80% of the class got an A- or better and 60% of the class got an A this time around (he released the distribution to us on Piazza). It's a class that I actually did learn quite a bit from, and I didn't need to attend lectures at all. Most of the problem sets were genuinely interesting in terms of content and challenge too (it was usually writing very few lines of code, but the challenge came in figuring out what was going on). 

That said, this course has some major logistical challenges to overcome. The slides were usually just borrowed from other courses without actually going through them in class. The problem sets were written by students and were hit or miss. Most were exceptional (the written pset that had us hard code neural nets by hand taught me a lot), but others (pset 4) were terrible, demanded knowledge that wasn't taught during the course at all (we were told to read the course material for CS231 at Stanford. Why am I taking a Yale class if I'm just being asked to read other schools' materials to do a problem set? This content should have been covered in class), and weren't fully done by the time they were released to students (many bugs that students had to point out and find fixes for). This is unacceptable. The other big issue is that the slides cover a ridiculously expansive set of content that just isn't covered in enough detail in the class. Studying for exams is a nightmare because there's just way too much content to review and it's unclear what's testable because the problem sets are completely different from the exams. The practice exams are unhelpful as they are ridiculously difficult problems from a Berkeley class that, unlike us, actually covered all the material from the slides. Make sure you ace the problem sets, do decently on the exams, and you'll get an A. This will get better over time, and I sincerely hope that the problem sets are written ahead of time next year.

I would recommend this class only if you want a very high level understanding of what AI has to offer and also have a spare Credit/D to use. The class was very disorganized in that the lectures, problem sets, and exams did not correspond with each other at all. Lectures moved very quickly because it was basically speeding through high level slides in an attempt to get through everything that might be of interest within the field of AI. Problem sets were written by the TFs and take largely from other courses at other schools. The material itself was pretty interesting and applicable on its own, but I think the class could have been much better organized in order to facilitate learning, because I think very few people felt like they actively understood anything after doing any of the problem sets.
I would recommend this to anyone interested in getting an overview of AI. I think it's a good fit for most backgrounds: no stats or math background necessary.

A good high-level AI class that also includes some exposure to lower-level implementation. Some stuff is relatively new, but for the most part expect to be learning about more basic/foundational stuff and older approaches to AI.

Awesome course. This course was a perfect combination of the foundations and modern techniques in AI. On the foundations side, we looked at search algorithms (depth-first, breadth-first, uniform cost / Dykstra, greedy best-first, A star + heuristics, and gameplay minimax with alpha-beta pruning); we showed the generality of these techniques with applications in gameplay, constraint satisfaction, and NP-complete problems. We also covered logic and theorem proving, decision trees, dimensionality reduction, probability, and Bayes nets. On the modern / sexy side, we covered neural nets in great detail (SVM, Softmax loss functions; stochastic gradient descent parameter updates; intuitions about hyperparamenters and convergence; fully-connected and convolutional layers for image classification and reinforcement learning; recurrent, LSTM, and attention architectures for semantic parsing). We also looked at Markov models (Markov reward processes, decision processes, POMDPs) and related algorithms (value and policy iteration, Q-learning) which was perhaps my favorite part of the course. 

This course also found a balance between theory and implementation. The lectures stay high-level, allowing for exposure to and synthesis of an immense field. In the psets, we dove in head first to the most crucial algorithms covered in class. The last two projects feature 1. (Supervized learning) - neural-net image classification on the CIFAR-10 data set and 2. Reinforcement Q-learning in the Pacman and Atari environments. Both projects were fun to show off to friends and family.

Why does it matter? In addition to its applicability in most jobs and areas of scientific and digital humanities research, AI is the noblest and most ambitious experiment undertaken by humankind (since freedom). In AI, we are trying to formalize the principles of our rationality, to extend and surpass our minds, to understand who and what we are. Join us!
I do not recommend taking this course. It suffers from a serious lack of structure.

The material is interesting and hopefully the level of organization will be higher in future years. Psets are taken from Berkeley and Stanford AI courses and are mostly fun to do. Relatively low workload for a CS elective. All the slides are posted online so the material is crammable.

I would not recommend taking this class for any reason. It is the worst class I have taken at Yale.

Unless they redesign the entire course, and the instructor seriously revamps his style of instruction, I would not recommend this course for any reason.

Don't take this class, it is a waste of time, you do not learn anything. Drago's lectures are extremely boring and uninformative. There is too much that he tries to cover in the course that you don't end up learning anything. The hardest part of this course was not knowing anything about probability-- a lot of the concepts in this course require probability concepts. 

You will end up doing a lot more work learning concepts on your own

I would recommend this course as a relatively easy CS elective to learn the basics of AI. That said, the class definitely has its weaknesses: this year, the material was disorganized, lecture was pretty boring, and psets were often irrelevant to what was covered in class. That said, if you're looking for a pretty lowkey CS elective to learn an overview of artificial intelligence, this is a fine class to take.
Unless serious changes to the course structure are made, I would recommend watching the UC Berkeley videos on AI and perhaps finding a different course, or taking NLP, which Drago seems to prefer.

Absolutely, taking this class was definitely worth it. I have improved and solidified the coding skills by far, learnt AI from scratch and enjoyed exploring the field through the extra material that was offered by the professor. It was very rewarding.

This is interesting material that is still being developed as we learn about it, which is super exciting! Because this course was in its first year, I think there was still a lot being developed/tested out. For example, Drago is a great professor (and his NLP class is definitely worth taking!) but a lot of the slides and problem sets ended up being taken directly from the Stanford or Berkeley slideshows and assignments. He did, however, do a great job of providing lecture slides and tons (and I mean TONS!) of extra links on Piazza if you wanted to learn more. I would recommend this course in future years, because I think it will be a bit better organized/material would be more organic. At the very least, you should take it to get an understanding of AI and to take a class with Drago-- he's adorably nice and sweet!

The topic is interesting and up-to-date. It covers a good breath in AI. The lectures and homework are mostly taken from classes at other schools though, so it feels that this class jumps from place to place. The lectures are not very engaging, as are many other cs classes, and Drago is trying to cover so much in this one course, so many lectures seem a little rushed, and requires a lot of learning on the students.
Yes, if you want to do anything CS related it is important to have an understanding of AI. At the least this class is a decent introduction.
Eh. First time it's been taught so maybe wait for them to work out the kinks.
There are better CS electives.

A decent survey course that somehow manages to cover the huge field that is AI in a single semester, though somewhat at the expense of depth and clarity. Don't take this if you only want to do statistics-based ML or deep learning (which is such a bubble anyway) -- be prepared to also learn about planning and search, logical reasoning, probabilistic reasoning, etc. (all of which are much more interesting intellectually, IMO). The content is good, though the slide-based lectures could probably be made more engaging (I'm a fan of chalk-board based explanations of algorithms, hopefully this happens next time round). Assignments can be a little more self-guided than you'd like, because you have to look up the documentation for ML libraries like Theano and Tensorflow yourself, but you also end up learning a lot along the way, and the overall workload ended up being not too high (especially with the deadline extensions they gave, when they realized some of the assignments were going to take way longer than planned). Overall, this is *much* better than the previous version of AI taught at Yale.
Highly recommend as it is a course in a field of computer science that is very relevant in the current frontier. However, be warned that much of it will be dwn to self studying

One of the most poorly organized classes that I've taken over the four years of my time at Yale. Psets were basically copy-pasted from Stanford/Berkeley's AI classes but in a degraded manner, and what's worse, the TAs clearly did not run or test them before they release the psets, so many of us had to waste so much time just debugging the pre-given code or installing a bunch of dependencies on the Zoo machines. Unless the class structure significantly improves, don't even think about taking it.
